I think it’s totally fine to prefer @elonmusk’s editorial taste to the Old Regime’s taste — you expect a change in ownership to entail a change in editorial taste. 

But you should have some questions as to why the new boss is making this out to be about something else.

Musk’s own preferred approach to content moderation is specifically to throttle disfavored accounts, exactly what Old Regime Twitter did. 

I assume his team will have a different take on which specific accounts deserve to be de-amplified. It’s his platform so be it. https://t.co/14qc3hMBbY

It was very interesting of @elonmusk and @bariweiss to pull back the curtain on the user interface and some of the process. But what I’d really like is fuller data — how were foreign government requests handled? How many people were flagged for de-amplification? Who exactly?

I think it’s fair to say that most people who complained about “shadowbanning” were complaining about what Twitter actually *did* do, not about this other thing that Twitter called “shadowbanning.” 

But there’s not some official definition we can appeal to for resolution.

To “shadow ban” is obviously not a term with a firmly established legal definition but when Old Regime Twitter officially denied shadowbanning they offered a specific, narrowly framed definition that seems consistent with New Regime Twitter’s revelations. https://t.co/wk382lDwzS

I sincerely urge people who think my tweets are *bad in general* to not voluntarily opt in to following them. 

You and I will both enjoy life more that way. But if you can’t bring yourself to unfollow I will assist with a block. https://t.co/U13BDN7fas

If @elonmusk wants to clearly demonstrate biased application of the rules, though, he needs to make some kind of complete database of these determinations public (or just give them to me so I can have a scoop). 

That said if he doesn’t want to, it’s his Twitter!

What sane people said back then was that it’s a private company that’s allowed to do what it wants and that continues to be true now that it’s Elon Musk’s company — there’s no big constitutional principle at stake here and we’ll see happens with a new approach.

Their content moderation policies were not achieving their stated goals around harassment and misinformation, left the platform with stagnant user growth, fueled constant resentment, and in my view largely backfired in terms of their partisan impact.

I think people should resist the urge to let rightwing clowning turn defense of the prior management team at Twitter into an important point of principle — at the time they were running the show everyone said, rightly, that they were doing a bad job.

tweets.text: What sane people said back then was that it’s a private company that’s allowed to do what it wants and that continues to be true now that it’s Elon Musk’s company — there’s no big constitutional principle at stake here and we’ll see happens with a new approach.

Their content moderation policies were not achieving their stated goals around harassment and misinformation, left the platform with stagnant user growth, fueled constant resentment, and in my view largely backfired in terms of their partisan impact.

I think people should resist the urge to let rightwing clowning turn defense of the prior management team at Twitter into an important point of principle — at the time they were running the show everyone said, rightly, that they were doing a bad job.

ChatGPT largely denies that gender differences reflect biology.

cc @hoovlet https://t.co/azZlgy4tUQ
@JoeGiacalone @nypmetro Apparently we shouldn't deter antisemitic behavior but have to address, what? The root causes? Those being...?
@MJWorth63 @mattyglesias MattY is firmly gen-x so take it up with them
Diesel prices still weirdly high, but gasoline now clearly down year-on-year. https://t.co/TWDjSfdku2

Well, I finally got a response to my proposal that Musk address his concern for political interference by publishing a database of moderation actions and communications with government actors. 

I just literally don't know what it means.

Proposal: https://t.co/BgrljBNvru https://t.co/VeJEAyqkIL

The Big Question is, has any arm of the US government been illegally and unconstitutionally outsourcing violations of citizens’ guaranteed rights under the 1st 4th and 5th Amendments to private entities.
@DavidSacks As @bariweiss clearly describes, the rules were enforced against the right, but not against the left

@mattyglesias Not hostile. Just pointing out that the point you are making is undermined by Twitter's own public TOS before 2022. That is all. 

Again, they were dishonest about what they were doing. As long as you admit that (which is quite clear now) then we are good. Facts matter.

@mattyglesias I mean, seeing they specifically targeted individual to ban their reach based on ideology seems a little bit more than yawn worthy.

I often thought the shadowban talk was just people being cranks.

Neoliberal midwit always apologizing for blatant left-wing censorship of people and ideas they don’t like. 

Gonna bring up Musk and muh China next? https://t.co/FiskP7pskt
We went quickly from “no one is being shadowbanned” to “we always knew people were being shadowbanned for ideological reasons; this is not new.” https://t.co/eXl2rHMBqn

@mattyglesias By the way...that is the current one from June. You might want to go back and look at the old one, say, in 2018. 

https://t.co/e7pB00jYV8

urls.title: Twitter Terms of Service

tweets.text:
@mattyglesias Both during Congressional hearings, as well as in filings to the FEC, they denied they were doing the things that now you claim everyone knew they were doing. 

Their TOS doesn't protect them from the legal implication of those lies.
@mattyglesias Strange then they lied about it under oath, no?

The problem is they literally denied they were doing this when asked under oath whether they were doing it. 

Multiple times. https://t.co/vJaB1rEOm2

urls.description: It’s hard to overstate the power of Smaker’s debut documentary. Spread the word about this film! COMING SOON OPENS tomorrow! Friday Dec. 9 A group of men trained by al-Qaeda are transferred from Guantanamo and sent to the world’s first rehabilitation center for “terrorists,” located in Saudi Arabia. Documentary, Politics & World Affairs, Justice Nominee, Grand Jury Prize ~ Documentary, Sundance Film Festival Empathy can an inherent part of the documentary form, but it seems to have been a speciality

tweets.text: If I understand correctly, shadowbanning helped Republicans because Twitter helped suppress the nuttiest ravings of the right? https://t.co/DJwtAiwgsv https://t.co/jYpA4Zxm2M
@mattyglesias You don't really believe that.  You're just in a certain mood over these revelations that harm your political identity and confidence in it.  A form of denial.

@mattyglesias #actually, þe white people of W. Virginia & E. Kentucky think þey hate Medicaid:þey hate charity from þe government, especially given at þe behest of a Black man. Þey want þe government to give þem þe opportunity to get good jobs so þey can EARN enough to pay for health insurance
Working on something where I was supposed to come up with 15-30 bullet points worth of political principles but I've really only got like 7 principles at best.
